{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3479705,"name":"Chris","username":"Chris_7898","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_7898/{size}/226133_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T03:29:05.665Z","cooked":"

Just a quick question about the Krakens. Today we were working on attempting to read what we thought was the fused can coder. We do not have a license for Phoenix Pro. Now my question is - Are the built in encoders Fused CAN coders? If not, what are they. Another thing is, what other options are there to read the output of the motor?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T03:29:05.665Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":777,"reads":313,"readers_count":312,"score":3952.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481110,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-built-in-encoder-and-output","display_username":"Chris","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5561 Prog Lead"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-built-in-encoder-and-output/481110/1","custom_user_title":"5561 Prog Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3479708,"name":"Alex","username":"aopalka","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f9ae1b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T03:31:40.761Z","cooked":"

They are relative encoders ( they will set the position to 0 when powered on ) , as opposed to absolute encoders which will retain there position when powered off . I’m pretty sure that fused encoders are a pro feature too ( but may be incorrect ). I’d wander over to the phoenix pro documentation and look it up.

The Fused CANcoders are a pro feature. But what output method would we use instead of the fused CANcoder? We tested the fused encoder today and it just wouldn’t give us the value because it is a pro feature we don’t have.

Something like :

image888×306 26.5 KB

In the following code you would be excluding the feedback sensor lines on the motor configuration :

image1936×810 127 KB

so you would want to look for anything where you are setting a Feedback like below and remove them :

fx_cfg.Feedback.FeedbackRemoteSensorID = m_cc.getDeviceID();
fx_cfg.Feedback.FeedbackSensorSource = FeedbackSensorSourceValue.FusedCANcoder;

So this looks like its using a remote CANcoder. Is that the only other way to get the position output? If so then we would have to move our serve CANcoders to the CANivore instead of the rio CAN.

You can use the CANCoder on the RIO canbus , or the CANivore. I would read the docs and figure out what works best for you : TalonFX Remote Sensors

Personally I read the cancoder value and set the motor’s relative encoder at startup. Do you really need absolute encoder continuously updating the motor ? The motor can track it once it gets updated from the absolute encoder.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T23:31:48.054Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":81.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481110,"topic_slug":"kraken-x60-built-in-encoder-and-output","display_username":"Alex","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/2024/docs/api-reference/device-specific/talonfx/remote-sensors.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"TalonFX Remote Sensors","clicks":28}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60542,"username":"Chris_7898","name":"Chris","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_7898/{size}/226133_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56954,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/kraken-x60-built-in-encoder-and-output/481110/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3480501,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T00:34:52.901Z","cooked":"

I think you’ve figured out what you need for your robot code, but I figured I’d answer some of your questions here.

Chris_7898:

Now my question is - Are the built in encoders Fused CAN coders? If not, what are they

The encoder built into the Kraken X60 is absolute to the motor rotor. That is, for a given rotor position, the motor will always boot to the same absolute position (which I believe has a range of [-0.5, 0.5) rotations). However, because this is absolute to the motor rotor, NOT to the mechanism, it is not very useful unless you are operating on a very small range of motion with a low gear ratio.

Chris_7898:

what other options are there to read the output of the motor?

To solve the absolute position issue, you can add an encoder like a CANcoder to the mechanism so you can get the absolute position after all your gear ratios. For CANcoder (and soon CANdi), there are a few ways to do this in Phoenix 6.

RemoteCANcoder uses the CANcoder-reported position instead of the Talon FX rotor. This does not require Phoenix Pro, but it comes with the downside that the update rate of the position/velocity values are limited by the CANcoder status signal update frequency. So if your CANcoder sends its position and velocity data every 10 ms (the default), then the Talon FX will only update its position and velocity every 10 ms, making the onboard PID run at only 100 Hz.

FusedCANcoder is a Pro-only feature that fuses the mechanism-absolute position of a CANcoder into the rotor position, providing a high-bandwidth absolute position. This allows the onboard PID to run at the full 1 kHz, since the rotor sensor is continuously updated between CANcoder updates.

There’s also SyncCANcoder (also requires Pro) for special circumstances where the CANcoder can fail while the motor’s connection to the mechanism is still fine. This has the downside of losing out on backlash compensation that you get with FusedCANcoder and RemoteCANcoder.

If you specify FusedCANcoder without Phoenix Pro, we automatically fall back to RemoteCANcoder. So you can always set up your code to use FusedCANcoder, then if you later decide you want Pro your devices will automatically switch over once they’re licensed.

Chris_7898:

If so then we would have to move our serve CANcoders to the CANivore instead of the rio CAN.

When using any of the remote feedback sensor sources, the remote sensor must be on the same CAN bus as the Talon FX(S). The only way around that is to use the internal rotor sensor and manually synchronize it to your CANcoder once in robot code, which is possible but prone to bugs if you’re not careful about things like checking status codes.
